Here are two comprehensive croissant recipes that will help you create perfect, flaky, buttery croissants at home.

## Classic French Croissants

This recipe comes from Parisian chef techniques and creates "flaky, buttery croissants from scratch, sharing chef secrets from Paris"[1](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RlFBTrqea2g).

**Ingredients for Dough:**
- 510g (1 lb 2 oz) all-purpose flour
- 65g (1/4 cup + 1 Tbsp) granulated sugar  
- 12g (2 1/2 tsp) fine sea salt
- 10g (1 Tbsp + 1/2 tsp) instant yeast
- 144g (5 oz) cold water
- 144g (5 oz) cold whole milk
- 43g (3 Tbsp) unsalted butter, softened

**For Butter Layer:**
- 284g (10 oz) cold, unsalted European butter like Kerrygold

**For Egg Wash:**
- 1 large egg
- 1 egg yolk
- Pinch of salt[1](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RlFBTrqea2g)

**Instructions:**
1. **Day 1 - Dough Preparation:** Mix flour, sugar, salt, and yeast. Combine cold water and milk, then incorporate into dry ingredients along with softened butter to form the détrempe (base dough).

2. **Prepare Butter Block:** "Place cold butter cubes between two sheets of parchment paper and use a rolling pin to pound and flatten it into a uniform square"[2](https://lacuisinedegeraldine.fr/en/homemade-croissants).

3. **Lamination Process:** Roll out dough, place butter block in center, and fold dough over butter. "Perform two folds (or 'turns'): One double fold (book fold) and one single fold, with resting time in between"[2](https://lacuisinedegeraldine.fr/en/homemade-croissants).

4. **Day 2 - Shaping:** Roll dough into rectangle, cut into triangles, and roll from wide end to tip. Let proof and bake with egg wash.

## Beginner-Friendly Croissants  

This recipe is designed to be "a bit" more accessible while maintaining authentic results[5](https://mxriyum.com/beginner-friendly-croissants/).

**Ingredients:**
- 250g (2 cups) all-purpose flour
- 250g (2 cups) bread flour
- 11g (1 tbsp) instant yeast
- 140g (0.59 cups) whole milk
- 140g (0.59 cups) cold water
- 50g (1/4 cup) sugar
- 10g (1 1/2 tsp) fine sea salt
- 55g (1/4 cup) high-quality unsalted butter, cold and cubed

**Butter Block:**
- 226g (2 sticks) high-quality butter[5](https://mxriyum.com/beginner-friendly-croissants/)

**Instructions:**

1. **Make Dough:** Combine both flours, yeast, milk, water, sugar, salt, and cubed butter. Mix until dough forms.

2. **Laminating:** "Remove the dough from the fridge and on a lightly floured surface, roll it out to 16×10". Remove the butter from the fridge & place it on top of the dough, right in the center"[3](https://baranbakery.com/easy-croissant-recipe/). 

3. **Folding:** "Fold the top and bottom 1/3 of the dough over the butter so they meet in the middle and seal the edges together"[3](https://baranbakery.com/easy-croissant-recipe/). Repeat this process 2-3 times with refrigeration between folds.

4. **Shaping:** "Cut the dough into 4-inch rectangles, then diagonally down the middle to create triangles. Stretch out the tail and top of each triangle slightly before rolling up"[5](https://mxriyum.com/beginner-friendly-croissants/).

5. **Final Proof:** "Arrange the rolled croissants, tail down, on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper" and "let them proof inside your oven (turned off) for 2 1/2 hours"[5](https://mxriyum.com/beginner-friendly-croissants/).

6. **Baking:** Brush with egg wash and bake until golden brown and flaky.

Both recipes require patience and proper technique, but the lamination process of folding butter into dough is what creates those signature flaky layers that make croissants so irresistible.

Citations:

Here are two excellent croissant recipes I found, each offering a different approach to making authentic French croissants at home.

## Recipe 1: Cédric Grolet's French Croissant Recipe

This professional chef's recipe from Léonce Chenal features **advanced techniques** and precise measurements used in high-end French patisseries.

**Ingredients:**
- **For the dough**: 1 kg (8 cups) all-purpose flour, preferably T45 pastry flour, 420 g (1¾ cups) water, 50 g (¼ cup) eggs, fresh yeast, salt, sugar, and honey[1](https://leoncechenal.com/french-croissant-recipe/)
- **Butter for lamination**: Beurre de tourage (laminating butter)
- **Additional**: Beurre pommade (softened butter)

**Key Steps:**
The recipe instructs to "combine the flour, water, eggs, fresh yeast, salt, sugar, and honey" in a mixing bowl with dough hook, then "mix until the ingredients form a homogeneous paste"[1](https://leoncechenal.com/french-croissant-recipe/). After initial mixing, you "add the beurre pommade and knead until the dough comes together"[1](https://leoncechenal.com/french-croissant-recipe/).

The lamination process involves placing "the beurre de tourage in the middle of the dough" and folding "the dough from each side over the butter to cover it completely"[1](https://leoncechenal.com/french-croissant-recipe/). The recipe requires making both a double fold and single fold, with the final instruction to "immediately roll out the dough to a thickness of 3.5 mm to start cutting and forming the croissants"[1](https://leoncechenal.com/french-croissant-recipe/).

## Recipe 2: Weekend Bakery Classic French Croissants

This recipe offers a **more accessible home-baker approach** with clear timing and yields about 15 croissants.

**Ingredients:**
- **Dough**: 500 g French Type 55 flour or unbleached all-purpose flour, 140 g water, 140 g whole milk (cold), 55 g sugar, 40 g soft unsalted butter, 11 g instant yeast, 12 g salt[2](https://www.weekendbakery.com/posts/classic-french-croissant-recipe/)
- **For laminating**: 280 g cold unsalted butter[2](https://www.weekendbakery.com/posts/classic-french-croissant-recipe/)
- **Egg wash**: 1 egg + 1 tsp water[2](https://www.weekendbakery.com/posts/classic-french-croissant-recipe/)

**Detailed Timeline:**
The recipe provides a practical three-day schedule. On Day 1, you "combine the dough ingredients and knead for 3 minutes, at low to medium speed, until the dough comes together"[2](https://www.weekendbakery.com/posts/classic-french-croissant-recipe/). The instructions emphasize that "you do not want too much gluten development because you will struggle with the dough fighting back during laminating"[2](https://www.weekendbakery.com/posts/classic-french-croissant-recipe/).

The final day includes precise timing: "09.00 h – Roll out to 20 cm x 110 cm," followed by "09.30 h – Divide and shape the croissants," then "09.40 h – First coat of egg wash"[2](https://www.weekendbakery.com/posts/classic-french-croissant-recipe/). The baking process concludes with "11.50 h – Bake for 15-18 minutes" resulting in finished croissants by "12.10 h – Ready!"[2](https://www.weekendbakery.com/posts/classic-french-croissant-recipe/)

## Key Differences

**Cédric Grolet's Recipe** uses professional techniques with honey and eggs in the dough, requiring more advanced skills and equipment. It focuses on achieving bakery-quality results with precise measurements and professional terminology.

**Weekend Bakery Recipe** provides a structured timeline approach perfect for home bakers, with clear instructions about gluten development and practical scheduling across three days. The recipe includes helpful timing cues and emphasizes techniques that prevent common home-baking mistakes.

Both recipes require **lamination technique** - the process of folding butter into dough to create flaky layers - but the Weekend Bakery version offers more detailed guidance for beginners while Grolet's recipe assumes professional knowledge.

Good — here’s a concise list of what croissant recipes typically require, broken into must-haves, very-helpful items, ingredient list (for a standard batch ~12–16 croissants), and optional shortcut/variation items. After this I’ll ask about your equipment so I can tailor a plan.

Equipment — must-haves
- Kitchen scale (accurate to ±1 g) — essential for lamination and consistent results  
- Rolling pin  
- Oven-safe baking sheets (2+), and parchment paper or silicone mats  
- Refrigerator and freezer (for chilling dough between turns)  
- Bench scraper (for dividing dough and handling)  
- Sharp knife or pizza wheel (for cutting triangles)  
- Pastry brush (for egg wash)  
- Measuring spoons/cups (for small items)  
- Large mixing bowl (or stand mixer bowl)

Very helpful (not strictly required)
- Stand mixer with dough hook (saves time/kneading energy)  
- Ruler or straight edge (for accurate shaping/cutting)  
- Instant-read thermometer (check fridge/room temps or butter temps)  
- Baking stone or steel (enhances oven spring)  
- Cooling racks  
- Parchment-folding clips or weights (for flattening butter block)  
- Dough sheeter (rare in home kitchens)

Ingredients — typical quantities for ~12–16 croissants (home-baker standard)
- Flour: 450–500 g (AP or bread flour; some recipes use a mix)  
- Water: ~140–160 g (adjusted by recipe)  
- Whole milk: ~120–160 g (some recipes use milk+water)  
- Salt: 10–12 g  
- Sugar: 40–60 g  
- Yeast: 8–12 g instant yeast (or equivalent fresh yeast)  
- Unsalted butter for dough (détrempe): 40–60 g (soft)  
- Unsalted butter for lamination (butter block): 250–300 g (cold, preferably high-fat/European-style if possible)  
- Egg wash: 1 large egg (or egg + yolk) with a splash of water or milk

Optional/variation ingredients
- Honey or malt syrup (small amount in some bakery recipes)  
- Custard, chocolate, almond paste, or ham & cheese for filled croissants  
- Extra butter type: “beurre de tourage” / laminating butter if you can get it

Common substitutions & notes
- Butter: European-style (82–85% fat) yields richer flavor and better layers; if unavailable, regular unsalted butter works but may be slightly softer.  
- Flour: Bread flour gives stronger gluten structure; AP works if you control mixing time.  
- Yeast: Instant yeast is easiest; active dry or fresh can be used with adjustments.  
- Shortcut: Use store-bought puff pastry or par-baked croissant dough for much simpler, faster results.

Timing & space requirements (general)
- Multi-day timeline: Many classic croissant recipes are 2–3 days (mix → laminate with rests → shape → proof → bake).  
- Active hands-on time: Several short sessions (mixing 15–30 min, lamination and turns 30–60 min plus chill time, shaping 30–60 min).  
- Cold chill space: You’ll need room in the fridge where you can rest the dough flat between turns (shelf space or shallow containers). Freezer space helps speed chills.

What I need from you next
- What equipment do you have available? (ovens, stand mixer, rolling pin, scale, fridge/freezer space, baking sheets, thermometer, etc.)  

Once you tell me your equipment I’ll:
- Recommend the best recipe approach (beginner, intermediate, or advanced) for your setup  
- Suggest ingredient tweaks and exact quantities for the batch size you want  
- Lay out a step-by-step timeline tailored to your available time and appliances.

Got it — no stand mixer. That’s fine; you can still make excellent croissants by hand. Quick notes before we proceed:

- Hand-mixing tips: mix the dough ingredients until they just come together in a shaggy mass, then turn out and knead briefly (5–8 minutes) until smooth — you want modest gluten development, not a long, elastic knead. Alternatively use the slap-and-fold method if dough is sticky.
- Keep everything cold: shorter mixing + colder liquids helps keep butter behavior predictable during lamination.
- Alternatives to a stand mixer: food processor (short pulses) or a strong wooden spoon/bench scraper and hand kneading.
- Expect a bit more elbow grease and slightly longer hands-on time, but no loss in final quality.
